Title:
Comparing Methods to Analyse Saturated and Compositionally
Heterogeneous Data
Keywords:
base composition heterogeneity, chi-square test of
homogeneity, mutational bias, substitutional saturation, systematic
error
Abstract:
Introduction: Model misspecification makes phylogenetic
analyses susceptible to systematic error, in which confidence on
incorrect resolutions increases with more data. Mutational bias at
neutrally evolving sites produces heterogeneous base composition among
taxa, causing systematic error. We compare eight phylogenetic methods in
analyses of a large phylogeny (>600 tips) based on one mammalian
mitochondrial gene with significant base composition heterogeneity at
saturated, neutrally evolving sites. Using hierarchical Bayesian
regressions, we modelled the probability of inferring clades (families
or genera) as a function of phylogenetic methods and clade-specific
characteristics. Results: Most methods incurred in misspecification from
mutational bias, and composition heterogeneity contributed to systematic
error for divergences between genera. Modelling the nucleotide
replacement process in many site categories or codon evolution were both
insufficient to overcome composition heterogeneity. Analysing the
protein alignment failed to improve overall inference despite no
heterogeneity in amino acid composition or loss of phylogenetic signal.
The best-performing method recoded nucleotides to purines and
pyrimidines at synonymous sites and analysed these as binary characters.
Conclusions: Evaluating the effects of base composition heterogeneity at
neutrally evolving sites is indispensable. Significant heterogeneity
needs to directly modelled or, when appropriate, addressed using
purine-pyrimidine and binary recoding. Unless base composition
heterogeneity is accounted for, ever-larger phylogenomic data sets may
incur in systematic error.
